start.title:
Outbreak

Modeling Viral Growth
start.start_body: Can you work alongside scientists to model a viral outbreak? In this STEAMQuest, you'll dive into exponential growth and discover how it's used to understand and predict how viruses spread!

intro.description:
Welcome to the Global Health Research Center.

Here, top scientists work every day to monitor and control disease outbreaks worldwide.
intro.aisha_intro: We've got an urgent situation on our hands. A new virus has been detected, and we need to model its spread quickly.
intro.chen_intro: When there is a disease outbreak, exponential functions can help us model how fast the disease will spread.

planning.heading: Explore Data Options
planning.planning_body:
The team gathers around a holographic map showing the disease outbreak data.

How would you like to start exploring the data?

examine_raw_numbers.chen_text_2: Let's look at the raw data and see if we can identify the pattern.
examine_raw_numbers.outbreak_text: Outbreak Data
examine_raw_numbers.outbreak_sub_text: Here's what we've recorded so far:
examine_raw_numbers.chen_explaining:
Look at how rapidly these numbers are increasing...
Can you spot the pattern and predict the cases for day 4?
examine_raw_numbers.aisha_conclusion_1:
This is alarming. The virus is spreading incredibly fast. It appears to be doubling each day!

If this trend continues, on day 4 there will be 1600 cases. And on day 5, we will see 3200 cases!
examine_raw_numbers.chen_text_4:
In an exponential model, we use the formula
N(t) = a • bt
N(t) is the number of cases at time t
a is the initial number of cases
b is the growth factor
t stands for time, or how many days have passed
examine_raw_numbers.chen_text_5: Let's fit the model to our data so that we can determine how fast the virus is spreading. On day 0, we had 100 cases. After 3 days, we had 800 cases.
examine_raw_numbers.chen_text_6:
Can you adjust the growth factor and the initial value to fit this model to our data?

N(t) = a • bt
examine_raw_numbers.exponential_function_subtitle: Move the sliders for a and b to find the model N(t) = a • bt.

about.heading: Understanding the Pattern
about.body:
• Study the pattern in the data table showing days 0-3
  • Notice how the number of cases changes each day
  • Use the pattern to predict day 4's cases

help.heading: Predicting Day 4 Cases
help.body:
Follow These Steps:

  1. Look at the data table
    • Start at day 0 with 100 cases
    • Watch how it changes each day
  2. Find the pattern
    • The number of cases each day = 2 times the number of cases from the previous day

For Day 4 Prediction:

  • Start with: 800 cases (day 3)
  • Multiply by: 2 (the pattern)
  • Result: 800 · 2 = 1600 cases

equation_about.heading: Function Notation Made Simple!
equation_about.body:
When we write N(t) = a · bt, remember:

  • N(t) is not multiplication! It means "number of cases at time t"
  • The value of t can be any number, but in this case, since t stands for days, and numbers greater than or equal to zero are valid values for t
  • When we write a · bt, we mean multiply the initial amount times the growth factor raised to t

Pro Tip: Think of N(t) as a prediction machine - put in time, get back a number of cases!

Remember: In N(t) = a · bt

  • Input: time in days t
  • Output: number of cases N(t)

graph_config.title: Exponential Growth of Cases
graph_config.subtitle: Showing increase in cases over time
graph_config.aria_label: The graph displays an exponential curve that can be adjusted using two sliders: one for the initial value (a) and another for the growth factor (b). The y-axis shows the number of cases, and the x-axis shows time in days. The curve demonstrates characteristic exponential growth, with the rate of increase becoming steeper over time.

help.heading: How to Find the Model
help.body:
Using the Sliders:

  1. Initial Value (a)
    • Set this to the number of cases on day 0
    • This is the starting point of your model
  2. Growth Factor (b)
    • Adjust this to match how quickly cases increase
    • Values greater than 1 show growth
    • Values less than 1 show decay

about.heading: About Exponential Functions
about.body:
An exponential function is any function of the form f(x) = a • bx, where a and b are constants with a ≠ 0, b > 0, and b ≠ 1, often modeling rapid growth or decay.

Formula:

N(t) = a • bt
, where:

  • a = initial value (number at time 0)
  • b = growth factor (how quickly it grows)
  • t = time (number of days)
  • N(t) = number of cases at time t

data_visualization.chen_text_2:
In an exponential model, we use the formula

N(t) = a • bt
N(t) is the number of cases at time t
a is the initial number of cases
b is the growth factor
t stands for time, or how many days have passed
data_visualization.chen_text_3:
Let's try to fit a model to our data. On day 0, we had 100 cases. After 3 days, we had 800 cases. Can you help me determine the model?

N(t) = a • bt
data_visualization.aisha_agreeing_text_1: That's correct. Exponential growth explains why we see a rapid acceleration in the number of cases.

growth_calculation.explain_text_1: With the exponential model established, the team can now make predictions about the future spread of the virus...
growth_calculation.aisha_text_1: How many cases do we predict to see on day 7?
growth_calculation.aisha_appreciating:
Excellent calculation!

Now, can you predict the number of cases you will see one week later, after 14 days?

interaction_1.title: Exponential Functions

about.heading: About Exponential Growth
about.body:
In this model, N(t) = 100 • 2t represents exponential growth where:

  • N(t): Number of cases on day t
  • 100: Initial number of cases (day 0)
  • 2: Growth factor (the number of cases doubles each day)
  • t: Number of days passed

help.heading: How to Predict the Cases
help.body:
Steps:

  1. Enter the number of days (t) in the input box
  2. Click the Calculate button
  3. View the predicted number of cases

For Day 5:

  • Enter t = 5
  • This calculates: N(5) = 100 • 25
  • 25 = 32
  • Final result: 100 • 32 = 3200 cases

interaction_1.input_left_text: t =
interaction_1.subtitle: Enter different numbers of days to see how the number of cases continues to change.

post_calculations.aisha_concluding_text_1: That sharp increase in just one week is alarming. Before we brief the response team, let's make sure we fully understand the implications of this growth.
post_calculations.aisha_explaining_text_1: If the outbreak continues to follow this exponential growth model, approximately how many days will it take for the number of cases to exceed 10 million?
post_calculations.aisha_appreciating_text_1:
Excellent work! You've grasped the power and danger of exponential growth.

We could be facing a massive health crisis if we don't act quickly. Your understanding of this mathematical model will help save lives.

Thank you for your assistance in this critical mission!

interaction_1.title: Exponential Functions

help.heading: Finding Time to Reach 10 Million Cases
help.body:
How to Find the Days Needed:

  • At 14 days, we predict 1,638,400 cases, so the number of cases will reach 10 million sometime after 14 days.
  • Enter values for t to determine when the number of cases exceeds 10 million.

about.heading: About Exponential Growth
about.body:
In this model,

N(t) = 100 • 2t
represents exponential growth where:

  • N(t)
    : Number of cases on day
    t
  • 100
    : Initial number of cases (day
    0
    )
  • 2
    : Growth factor (the number of cases doubles each day)
  • t
    : Number of days passed

interaction_1.subtitle: Enter different numbers of days to see how the number of cases continues to change.

pre_ending.aisha_praise: Excellent work! You've grasped the power and danger of exponential growth when it comes to viruses. Your understanding of this mathematical model will help save lives.
pre_ending.chen_talks_about_formula:
The exponential function
N(t) = a • bt
proved vital in predicting the outbreak's progression. You showed how small numbers can become dangerously large in just a matter of days.
pre_ending.aisha_concern: We could be facing a massive health crisis if we don't act quickly. Your calculations show we must implement containment measures immediately, before these numbers become overwhelming.
pre_ending.chen_give_thanks_aisha: Thank you for your contribution to this critical mission. Remember - in epidemiology, mathematical modeling doesn't just solve equations, it saves lives. Your work today will help protect communities worldwide.

quest_completion.content:
You've successfully completed the Outbreak: Modeling Viral Growth STEAMQuest.

  • •You discovered exponential functions in disease spread modeling
  • •You used N(t) = 100 · 2ᵗ to predict future cases
  • •You learned why early intervention is critical in outbreak control

Keep going! Your journey of exploring mathematical modeling continues.

exponential.definition: Exponential means growing very quickly by repeatedly multiplying by the same number (like doubling or tripling each time).

raw_data.definition: Raw Data is information in its original, unprocessed form (like just the numbers before they're put into a graph).

model.definition: Model means using math to show how something works in real life, usually with a formula.

holographic_map.definition: Holographic Map is a 3D map that floats in the air. Scientists can walk around it and see it from all sides.

growth_factor.definition: Growth factor is the number that a quantity is multiplied by after a unit of time in exponential function. For example, if a quantity triples every second, the growth factor is 3.

epidemiology.definition: Epidemiology is the study of how diseases spread and affect populations. It helps scientists understand patterns of infection, risk factors, and ways to prevent and control outbreaks.

initial_value.definition: Initial Value is the starting amount or condition in a mathematical function or equation, often represented as a in exponential growth models.

exponential_functions.definition: An exponential function represents a quantity that increases or decreases by the same quantity for every unit of time. For example, a quantity that doubles every year.

common.x_units_y_dollars_label: Where x is the number of units and c is the total amount in dollars
common.invalid_input_submitted: One or more inputs are invalid!
common.aisha_patel_description: An Indian doctor named Aisha Patel in a white lab coat with a stethoscope.

common.bg2_description: Scientists analyzing global data on interactive screens in high-tech laboratory.
common.bg3_description: Modern control room with world map display and monitoring stations.
common.bg4_description: Laboratory interior with blue technological ambient lighting and workstations.
common.bg5_description: Research team working with global data displays in modern lab.
common.bg6_description: Scientists monitoring global data on multiple screens in control center.

profitability.definition: Measure of how much money a business makes after subtracting all its costs.

revenue.definition: The total amount of money earned from selling goods or services.

linear_function.definition: A function that represents a straight line on a graph.
